description.narrative: 1. Creating sufficient jobs that are adequately remunerative and sustainable across the economy, 2. Equipping the workforce with vital skills and attitude for increasing productivity that are needed for the private sector growth, and 3. Provide a national framework for coordinating all employment related initiatives and activities in the public, private and civil society.

Sverige har blivit ombett att bidra till Rwandas nationella sysselsättningsprogram National Employment Program (NEP). NEP är ett nytt program som har skapats för att stödja Rwandas långsiktiga utvecklingsstrategi där produktiv sysselsättning ses som nyckeln till att lyfta befolkningen ut ur fattigdom.
NEP har tre utvecklingsmål: 1) att skapa hållbara jobb som ger skälig inkomst; 2) att erbjuda utbildning som efterfrågas på den privata arbetsmarknaden; och 3) att skapa ett nationellt ramverk för koordinering av alla sysselsättningsfrämjande insatser i Rwanda. Tre huvudsakliga metoder ska användas för att uppnå dessa mål. För det första ska NEP stärka den privata sektorn genom att erbjuda coachning av och tillgång till kapital för nystartade, små och medelstora företag. För det andra så ska NEP öka arbetskraftens anställningsbarhet genom att erbjuda korta yrkessutbildningar och tekniska utbildningar för personer som står utanför arbetsmarknaden samt förmedla praktikplatser för personer som examinerats från längre utbildningar. Och för det tredje så ska NEP erbjuda de allra fattigaste och mest marginaliserade grupperna på arbetsmarknaden temporärt offentligt arbete med utbildning på arbetsplatsen för att öka deras anställningsbarhet. NEP uppfyller också en koordineringsfunktion kring sysselsättningsfrämjande insatser i Rwanda med syftet att effektivisera användning av knappa resurser.
NEP är ett femårigt program och det svenska stödet bidrar till budgeten genom programstöd under de första tre åren, mellan november 2014 och juni 2017. Sveriges sammanlagda bidrag under den perioden är SEK 100 miljoner. Sverige är för tillfället den största bilaterala givaren till programmet. Den största delen av budgeten (ca 80%) täcks av Rwandas regering.

The National Employment Program (NEP) is organized under four pillars: (i) skilld development, (ii) entrepreneurship and business development, (iii), labour market interventions, and (iv) coordination and M&E. The project aims at increasing the skills base of the Rwandan labor force to promote employability of the weaker actors and to reach higher levels of productive employment.

participating-org.narrative: NEP/Ministry of Public Serv&Labor, Kigali/National Employment Program

description.narrative: Sweden is funding Rwanda’s National Employment Programme (NEP) with 160 million SEK over five years, 2014 – 2019. The funding has been subject to two sequential agreements, i.e. 100 million SEK for three fiscal years 2014-2017 and 60 million SEK for two fiscal years 2017-2019. This completion of contribution concerns the first agreement 2014-2017 of 100 million SEK. The purpose of NEP is to address one of Rwanda’s main development challenges, namely to create sufficient productive employment opportunities, i.e. yielding enough income to allow the worker and his/her family/dependents a living standard above the poverty line. Rwanda´s government has over the last five years had the ambition to create 200,000 off-farm jobs per year and NEP is an important contribution to that goal. After the fiscal year 2016/2017, Rwanda's Local Development Agency, LODA, estimated the total annual number of off-farm jobs created to 233,190. This is over 30,000 more new jobs than expected. NEP activities were estimated to have created 46,206 off-farm jobs which is 61.8% more than the expected. This means that NEP contributes to almost 20% to the total estimated number of created off-farm jobs. NEP has achieved important results and is now established as a facilitator for the nation-wide employment promotion. NEP has built a satisfactory organisation and management structures, which has sufficient resources to deliver planned result. The Government has been very committed to the objectives of the programme and NEP is the preferred facility for employment interventions. NEP has achieved a great deal in terms of providing a national framework for coordinating all employment interventions in the country. NEP has enhanced and improved local structures for employment creation including Business Development Units in each District, enhanced local presence by the Business Development Fund (BDF), two independent Business Development Advisors (BDA) in each sector unit (amounting to more than 800 BDAs across the country) and greater access to finance for business start-up for those who normally don't have access to finance. District BDF offices and the selected local Savings and Credit Cooperatives (SACCOs), which provide NEP financial instruments to small businesses report that their activities now have a better outreach and they have more clients/members than before NEP. Another important issue is to what extent the interventions include women. NEP has made efforts to reach women through so called mobilisation and awareness campaigns to get more women beneficiaries and the number has increased steadily for different interventions. However, the main problem is that implementing institutions are not gender aware and interventions are not gender sensitive, which makes it difficule to have any real impact on women. NEP Secretariat has worked jointly with MIGEPROF (Ministry of Gender and family) to raise the capacities of implementing institutions in gender analysis and intervention design.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
